title: How to Make a Meatza

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400°F (204°C) and line a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) pizza pan with parchment paper.
Mix together the egg and ground beef in a large mixing bowl, then add the Italian seasoning.
steps.description: The egg acts as a binder in this recipe, so it helps hold the meat together. You can to combine the meat and egg first, otherwise, the herbs won't mix in properly. Add 1 minced garlic clove for extra flavor. You can mix the ingredients together using a rubber spatula or a wooden spoon. You can also use your hands, but be sure to put on a pair of plastic gloves first.

steps.headline: Spread the meat mixture evenly across the pizza pan.
steps.description: Place the meat into the pan first, then flatten it, making it go almost all the way to the edges. If you don't own a pizza pan, you can use any other baking pan instead—it can even be a square or rectangle! Keep in mind that you may have to adjust the baking times. The meatza will create lots of grease. To prevent making a mess, consider setting the pizza pan down into a larger baking dish to catch any grease that might runoff.

steps.headline: Bake the meatza for about 20 to 25 minutes, then pour off any excess grease.
steps.description: The meatza is ready when the meat is browned around the edges.

steps.headline: Pour the excess fat off, then remove the parchment paper.
steps.description: Once the meatza is baked, take it out of the oven, then pour off any excess grease into the trash. Carefully pull out the parchment paper, but leave the meatza on the pan. Do not pour the fat into the sink, or it will clog the drains as it solidifies.

steps.headline: Spread the sauce on top.
steps.description: Spoon the sauce randomly on top of the meat crust, then swirl it together. You can do this using the back of a spoon or a rubber spatula. Try to spread it as evenly as you can, but leave a 1 to 2-inch (2.54 to 5.08-centimeter) border for the crust.

steps.headline: Add some cheese, if desired.
steps.description: Some people choose to leave the cheese out for a slightly healthier meatza, but others choose to leave it on for a more traditional "pizza." You can use any type of cheese you want, but Cheddar goes especially well with beef.

steps.headline: Add some toppings.
steps.description:
What toppings you add, and how many, is entirely up to you! Plan on using about ½ cup (50 to 100 grams) of each topping that you add. Here are some ideas to get you started:
Chopped bell pepper
Chopped tomatoes
Pepperoni
Sliced onion

steps.headline: Bake the meatza for 15 more minutes.
steps.description: The meatza is ready when the cheese is melted and turns a golden-brown color at top.

steps.headline: Slice the meatza into fourths, then serve it.
steps.description: If you made a rectangular meatza, cut it into 8 or 9 rectangles instead.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400°F (204°C).
steps.description: Make sure that the baking rack is in the center of the oven.

steps.headline: Mix together the ground beef, dried herb, basil, garlic clove, salt, and pepper in a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: You can use any type dried herbs you want, as long as they go well with beef. Oregano, thyme, and parsley go especially well together. You can mix the ingredients together using a wooden spoon or rubber spatula, or you can use your hands. If you decide to use your hands, be sure to put on a pair of plastic gloves. This will keep your hands clean. For a chicken meatza, try: 1 pound (454 grams) ground chicken, 1 minced garlic glove, and 1 teaspoon Italian herb. For a Greek meatza, try: 1 pound (454 g) of ground lamb, 1 egg, ½ to 1 tablespoons of fresh thyme, 1 teaspoon of dried oregano, ¼ teaspoon of dried onion powder, 1 teaspoon of salt, and 1 finely chopped garlic clove.

steps.headline: Divide the mixture in half, then press each half into an 8-inch (20.32-centimeter) pie pan.
steps.description: Separate the meat into two parts, then roll each part into a ball. Press one of the balls into your first pan, then flatten it out, making sure to cover just the bottom of the pan. Wet your hands with water, then smooth the meat down until it is the same thickness throughout. Repeat the process for the other pan with the remaining meat ball. If you don't have pie pans, you can use other baking dishes instead. You can also make one big pizza in a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02-centimeter) baking pan.

steps.headline: Bake the meat for 10 to 15 minutes, or until it is done.
steps.description: If you are baking a thicker crust, the meatza may take up to 20 to 25 minutes to cook. It is ready when the meat is browned around the edges.

steps.headline: Take the pans out of the oven.
steps.description: There will likely be lots of fat gathered in the pan, so pour it into a can and discard it (or reserve it for cooking). Set the meatzas aside to cool while you prepare the sauce and toppings. Do not pour the fat down the sink, or it will clog the drains once it hardens.

steps.headline: Prepare your pizza seasoning if you wish to use a homemade sauce.
steps.description: If you already have a sauce that you'd like to use, then you can skip this step and click here to continue. In a small bowl, combine 4 teaspoons of each of the following: dried oregano, dried basil, and dried parsley. Add 2 teaspoons of coarse garlic powder, 1 teaspoon of salt, 1 teaspoon of onion salt, and ½ teaspoon of crushed red pepper flaked. Stir everything together. Measure out 1 teaspoon, then store the rest in a glass jar.

steps.headline: Start heating the oil, garlic, and seasoning for your pizza sauce.
steps.description: Start by heating a small saucepan over low heat. Once it is hot, add 1 teaspoon of olive oil, 1 minced garlic clove, and 1 teaspoon of your prepared pizza seasoning; do not use all of the seasoning. Stir everything together, then let it cook for about 20 seconds.

steps.headline: Add the tomato paste and water, then simmer the sauce for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Stir in 3 ounces (85 grams) of tomato paste. Once it is evenly mixed in with the oil, stir in ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of water. Bring the sauce to a boil over medium to medium-high heat, then immediately reduce the heat to low. Let the sauce simmer for 5 minutes, or until it turns thick.

steps.headline: Spread the sauce onto your meatzas.
steps.description: You will need about ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of sauce for each meatza. If you made one big meatza, you can use all of the sauce. Spread the sauce in an even layer across the meatza, leaving a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) boarder.

steps.headline: Consider adding some cheese.
steps.description:
Most chefs choose to forgo the cheese to make the meatza healthier, but you can add a sprinkle of it, if you'd like. Choose cheese that goes well with your choice of meat and toppings. Here are some ideas to get to you started:
For a marinara meatza, use shredded mozzarella cheese. For a chicken meatza, consider Parmesan cheese and/or mozzarella cheese. For a Greek meatza, try: ¼ cup (25 grams) of crumbled feta cheese.

steps.headline: Add the rest of your toppings.
steps.description: You can add just about anything you want on top of your pizza. You can use everything from the list included in the recipe, or just a few items, or you can experiment with your own toppings. Plan on using up to ½ cup (50 to 100 grams) of each topping. Save delicate toppings, such as arugula leaves and basil, for last. For a marinara meatza, use 2 diced, small Roma tomatoes and ¼ cup (5 grams) of thinly sliced fresh basil. For a Greek meatza, consider: ½ cup (50 grams) of pitted kalamata olives, ½ small, thinly-sliced red onion. chopped green bell pepper, sliced cherry tomatoes, and arugula leaves. Give it a veggie spin. Use ½ cup (100 grams) of chopped tomatoes, ⅓ cup (35 grams) of chopped mushrooms, ¼ cup (40 grams) each of chopped onion and chopped bell pepper. Top it off with ½ teaspoon each of following: Italian seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder.

steps.headline: Bake the pizza for 10 to 15 more minutes, or until the top of the meatza is browned to your liking.
steps.description: The meat should be completely cooked through by this point.

steps.headline: Cut each pizza into fourths, then serve it.
steps.description: If you made your pizza in a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02-centimeter) baking pan, cut it into 8 or 9 rectangles instead.

steps.headline: Finished.
